fields.description: A few of the features: Mary Ellen Barry presents a start-to-finish training plan for teaching your dog to perform the broad/long jump completely independently, Tracy Sklenar suggests methods for integrating 2x2 weave pole training into agility classes, Dara Tarolli explains the importance of secondary reinforcement in agility training, Pamela Dennison explains what obedience foundation behaviors are necessary for reactive or aggressive dogs attending agility classes and trials, Sandy Rogers looks at verbal turn cues in the second of a two-part article, Kristy Netzer shows us how to handle gambles that contain a lateral distance challenge, Nancy Gyes shares exercises for practicing straight-ahead sends, a group of vets provides an update on Canine Cruciate Disease, and much more! 84 pages.

A few of the features: Mary Ellen Barry shares exercises for maintaining your dog's weave pole entry skills, Tracy Sklenar helps instructors develop training plans for their students, Kathy Miller shares how she applied Sally Swift's Centered Riding techniques to agility in order to improve her mental game, Susan Klavon explains how to use an agility journal to get the most from every run, Pamela Dennison demonstrates how to teach the foundation behaviors needed by the reactive dog, Kristy Netzer shows us how to handle gambles that contain a redirect challenge, Brenna Fender talks to spouses who do agility togeter, a vet discusses treatments and preventative measures for hip dysplasia in puppies, three handlers (Greg Derrett, Rachel Sanders, and Jane Simmons-Moake) evaluate an agility course, and much more! 84 pages.

A few of the features: Daisy Peel discusses how to evaluate the training articles in Clean Run as well as all the books and DVDs on agility training so that you can decide which information is relevant to your team, Sassie Joiris shares her formula for achieving focus, drive, and desire in any dog, Dr. Julie Roos examines the medical issues surrounding early spay and neuter procedures, Tracy Sklenar provides tips to instructors for getting your point across to your students, Brenna Fender introduces us to the leaders of the different agility organizations in the first of a two-part article, Jamie McKay begins a new series aimed at the novice agility competitor, Andrea Dexter shares tips for training and planning strategies for the NADAC Chances class, Stuart Mah begins a new series of training drills, Pamela Dennison continues her series on dealing with aggressive and reactive dogs, Jane Killion helps you teach your dog to love the teeter, Sandy Rogers finishes her series on turn cues by demonstrating how you can combine the cues, Nancy Gyes puts up drills based on courses from the 2010 FCI Agility World Championships, and much more! 84 pages.

Susan Salo shares exercises for managing dogs that take off early for jumps, Dr. Debbie Gross Saunders explains how overtraining affects us and our dogs, Pamela Dennison demonstrates how to set up desensitization sessions for aggressive or reactive dogs, Daisy Peel shares ideas for achieving balance in our agility training, Brenna Fender introduces us to the leaders of the different agility organizations in the second of a two-part article, Jamie McKay explains how to find and enter agility trials, Andrea Dexter shares tips for training and handling tunnels as well as planning strategies for the NADAC Tunnelers class, Stuart Mah sets up exercises that require handlers and dogs to rapidly shift from obstacle focus to handler focus multiple times, Annie Pyle challenges us with drills that test weave pole entries and exits, Tracy Sklenar describes classroom games that can help get students more involved in class, Tinna Brown provides tips for running a great trial, and much more! 84 pages.

fields.title: We Just Do This for Fun

fields.description: Weave pole spacing, displaceable tire, veterans program, performance program changes.
fields.series: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Dog Agility
fields.title: Explanation of USDAA rule changes

fields.tags: courses, exercises, front cross, rear cross, serpentine
fields.title: Serpentines, Front and Rear Crosses

fields.description:
Performing the long jump (a.k.a.
broad jump) is required in AKC
Novice and USDAA Steeplechase
classes, yet it is often undertrained.
Here’s a simple start-tofinish
training plan for the long
jump.
fields.title: How to Train the Long Jump

fields.description:
Agility is fun, exhilarating, and
exciting. But that shouldn’t preclude
good manners and calm,
focused behaviors at all times.
Dogs that have an “edge” or that
are over-the-top at agility class
or trials, lunging and barking at
dogs or people, need foundation
behaviors to help them
succeed in agility and in life.
fields.series: Dealing with Aggression in the Performance Dog
fields.title: You Know Your Dog Is Aggressive If... Part 1

fields.description:
Need some training ideas for maintaining your
dog’s agility skills? This series presents a maintenance
program that is easy to implement and
that is designed to accomplish a great deal in
short sessions. This month focuses on long/
broad jump behaviors.
fields.title: The Long Jump

fields.description:
Cranial cruciate ligament (CCL) deficiency is
the most common cause of hind limb lameness
in the canine. In the second article of this twopart
series, we explore treatment of the disease.
fields.title: A Review of Canine Cruciate Disease, Part 2

fields.description:
We continue to explore turning the dog with
verbal cues. Physical cues are successful when
you’re in the correct position to execute them.
But if you are often caught far enough behind
your dog that you can no longer influence him
with physical cues, then you should train your
dog to turn when he hears a verbal command
such as Left, Right, or Turn.
fields.title: Cue #7: Verbal Left and Right Cues, Part 2

fields.series: Nested Courses for a Small Universe
fields.title: Complications for weave entries

fields.description:
In this month’s setup you have ample opportunities
to practice your Go On cues up or down a
line of jumps as well as straight-ahead sends out
of straight tunnels.
fields.title: Short Courses and Drills

fields.description:
One thing that makes the table so
challenging is many dogs appear to
do the table perfectly at home, yet
they have terrible table performances
at a trial. How can you train past something
that only happens in the heat of
a trial? This month we’ll show you.
fields.title: The Perfect Table, Part 2

fields.description:
Touch N Go is a NADAC game
where the course consists of “touch”
obstacles (A-frame and dogwalk) and
“go” obstacles (tunnels and hoops).
Challenges come from performance of
the obstacles themselves, obstacle discrimination,
off-course potential, and
basic handling.
fields.tags: NADAC, handling, strategy, touch n go
fields.title: Touch N Go Strategy and Tips

fields.description:
While many competitors dream of earning
titles, animal shelters continue to house dogs
that were relinquished because they are too
energetic, too smart, or too busy for most pet
homes. Many of these dogs are great agility
prospects. This month, meet Hailey McBean,
a Catahoula Leopard Dog.
fields.title: Hailey McBean

fields.description:
Weave pole training with 2 x 2s
is an incredibly effective method
for teaching dogs to weave
in the comfort of your backyard,
but this training method can
also work in group agility classes.
Here are some suggestions
for using 2 x 2s in your classes.
fields.title: 2 x 2s Aren’t Just for the Backyard: Training with the 2 x 2 Method in Group Agility Classes

fields.description:
Sometimes you can’t reward
your dog immediately. In these
cases, you can teach the dog
that something you can give
him immediately represents
something that he naturally
wants.
fields.title: Secondary Reinforcement in Agility

fields.description:
There are two types of lateral distance work.
The first is using an Out command to push
the dog away from you, indicating that you
want him to change his path. The other is using
the Go command to keep him on his path at a
distance. Learn how to teach both skills.
fields.title: Lateral Distance

fields.description:
Entering more than one dog in a trial
means more fun, but it also means possible
ring con icts. The need to be in
two places at once causes major stress
for some handlers. Here are some suggestions
on handling ring con icts.
fields.title: Dealing with those Confounding Conflicts

fields.description: Many competitors don't know anything about the people who help organize and orchestrate most aspects of this well-loved sport. This month you'll meet Sharon Nelson (NADAC) and Ken Tatsch (USDAA).
fields.series: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Dog Agility
fields.title: Agility Organization Leaders, Part 1

fields.description: Whether your goal is to earn a few ribbons or a championship title, you owe it to yourself and your teammate to set yourself up for success before stepping into the ring for the first time.
fields.title: Ready, Set, Trial!

fields.description: Chances is a game where most, or all, of the course must be handled from within a restricted area and within a fixed amount of time. Here are some tips for training necessary skills and planning a handling strategy.
fields.title: NADAC Chances Strategy and Tips

fields.description: Once you and your dog have a good understanding of the various directional commands discussed in past articles in this series, the next step is working on gambles themselves.
fields.title: Work that Line! How to Plan the Perfect Gamble

fields.description: You should be able to put your dog into a tunnel, either in obstacle focus or handler focus, and have the dog come out with the same focus. These exercises will help you work on that skill.
fields.title: Challenges for Rising Stars

fields.description: Once you have the dog's foundation behaviors trained, it's time to concentrate on your skills. You are going to work on reacting quickly and not freezing, being proactive rather than reactive, and practicing positive mental imagery.
fields.series: Dealing with Aggression in the Performance Dog
fields.title: You Know Your Dog Is Aggressive If... Part 3

fields.description: This month's drills are inspired by the courses the AKC/USA team ran at the 2010 FCI Agility World Championships in Germany, and specifically, a sequence from judge Nalle Jansson's Large Dog Individual Jumpers course. It was both an interesting and challenging course.
fields.title: Sequence from Large Dog Jumpers

fields.description: Does your dog hate repetition in training? Get easily distracted? Or shut down as soon as he thinks he's wrong or as soon as you make a mistake? There is a way to achieve focus, drive, and desire in virtually all dogs without having the best reinforcers or the best handling skills.
fields.series: The Secret to Focus, Drive, and Desire
fields.title: Training

fields.description: Despite all the great resources and advancements in agility training, many teams still find it difficult to put together a reliable teeter performance. To be successful with the teeter, you need to focus on training the dog's entire performance, not just the obstacle.
fields.title: Learning to Love the Teeter

fields.description: Regional tournament events draw top competitors, and the course designs for these events are generally quite challenging. Elements from these courses are frequently inspiration for judges and often set trends in course design at the local level. This month's sequence is taken from the USDAA Team Standard course at the Rocky Mountain Regional held in Farmington, Utah in June 2010.
fields.title: Team Standard Course

fields.description: Now that you've learned the seven turn cues, it's time to put the turns together and have some fun creating turn-cue combinations. Combining the turn cues is the next step in perfecting your turn-cue communication with your dog. The combos can also help you perfect your footwork and make your timing more consistent.
fields.title: Combining Turn Cues

fields.description: Since most agility students are well into adulthood, it is important for instructors to understand how to best work with adult learners. Here are some techniques that will help you get your point across to your students.
fields.title: Instructional Techniques for Working with Adult Learners.

fields.description: There is a lot of information in the magazine. How do you evaluate each article (and all the other information that comes your way) so you can choose methods that are compatible with your mindset, your lifestyle, your training and handling, and your dog?
fields.title: How Do You Decide What Information in Clean Run Is Relevant to You?

fields.description: Early spay and neuter has become a hot topic in the agility world. You hear horror stories about what can happen if you do spay your dog at six months and stories about what can happen if you wait too long. What to believe?
fields.title: Early Spay and Neuter in Dogs: A Discussion of the Medical Issues

fields.description: Canine hip dysplasia (CHD) is one of the most common orthopedic diseases of medium- and large-breed dogs. It can lead to pain, arthritis, and decreased quality of life. There are many treatment options for CHD as well as preventive measures that can be taken.
fields.title: Hip Dysplasia in Puppies

fields.description: The final skill for your Gamblers work is teaching your dog the redirect. This cue is the most complex of the directional skills that you’ll teach your dog. Essentially, the redirect is a rear cross done at a distance, but you don’t actually cross behind your dog or the obstacle.
fields.tags: cross, distance, gamblers, rear cross, training
fields.title: The Redirect

fields.description: Spouses who do agility together have mostly good things to say about sharing their agility passion. Most agility couples train, travel, and trial together, and they think doing so has some major advantages. But there can also be a few challenges to coupling up for agility.
fields.title: Married to Agility

fields.description: You can use an agility journal not only to track your performance, but also to plan handling strategies and warm-up routines for your dog, develop homework to improve skills, and even practice course analysis and game strategy skills.
fields.tags: course analysis, handling, practice, strategy, trialing
fields.title: Use an Agility Trial Journal to Get the Most from Every Run

fields.description: Need some training ideas for maintaining your dog’s agility skills? This series presents a maintenance program that is easy to implement and that is designed to accomplish a great deal in short sessions. This month focuses on weave entries.
fields.title: Weave Entrances

fields.description: Three handlers with different styles of handling analyze the same course and share their handling strategies. This month they look at an AKC Excellent Standard course by judge Deidre Crofton.
fields.title: AKC Excellent Standard Course

fields.description: These exercises are about learning to execute tunnel/contact discriminations at speed and learning to thoughtfully direct the dog through a short technical sequence at either end of the discrimination.
fields.title: Tunnel Contact Discriminations

fields.description: Agility is fun, exhilarating, and exciting. But that shouldn’t preclude good manners and calm, focused behavior at all times. Dogs that have an “edge” or that are over-the-top at agility class or trials, lunging and barking at dogs or people, need foundation behaviors to help them succeed in agility and in life. Here’s how to teach those behaviors.\
fields.series: You Know Your Dog Is Aggressive If...
fields.title: Part 2

fields.description: Top competitors from over 30 nations, including the U.S., commit to attend the European Open each year, rain or shine. You wouldn’t necessarily think rain on a late July weekend in Europe, but that’s exactly what confronted dogs and handlers in Liberec, Czech Republic.
fields.title: European Open
Training exercises focusing on distance work.

fields.description: A Standard agility nested training course for multiple levels.
fields.series: Nested Courses for a Small Universe
fields.title: Nested Standard course.

fields.description: Training for agility without a plan is like baking without a recipe. As instructors, we need to impress upon our students the importance of having a plan. We also need to help students develop that plan, and then support and motivate them as they implement the plan.
fields.title: Developing Training Plans for Students

fields.description: Do you get stage fright in the ring or have trouble with ring nerves? Learn how to apply Centered Riding principles to agility. It will help with your mental game and increase your confidence and clarity in competition.
fields.title: Applying Sally Swift’s Centered Riding Techniques to Dog Agility

fields.series: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Agility
fields.title: Qualifying for USDAA Cynosports and UKI Agility

fields.description: Training exercises focusing on teaching the dog responsibility for finding jumps.
fields.title: Teaching responsibility for finding jumps.

fields.description: Rather than always doing the same thing in your agility classes, shake things up a bit by playing games that are designed to get students thinking outside the box and get them involved in class.
fields.title: Handling Games to Get Students Thinking and Having Fun

fields.description: Tunnelers is a NADAC game where teams run a course consisting of tunnels, tunnels, and more tunnels. While we’ll discuss game-specific strategy in this article, we’ll also look at strategies for handling and training tunnels that can be applied to any agility course that includes tunnels.
fields.tags: NADAC games handling strategy training tunnels
fields.title: NADAC Tunnelers Strategy and Tips

fields.description: When a dog has an injury, at what point do you look in the mirror and ask yourself who you’re really doing agility for? Does your dog really care if he only needs one more Double-Q for a MACH5? And does earning that title change your relationship with your dog? If a dog needs medication for pain, then he does not need to be trialing.
fields.title: When Is Enough Enough?

fields.description: All of us have to face that our dog’s agility career is going to end. But how do we know when it’s time? Maybe when it’s time, the moment will present itself; so perhaps it’s better to focus on the journey and day-to-day living.
fields.title: Sera’s Story: Musings from An Agility Journey

fields.description: There are no fixes for early takeoff problems. But with hard work and going back to square one with foundation jumping grids, you can manage the problem and increase the dog’s confidence, making the game of agility fun again for both handler and dog.
fields.title: Early Takeoff: A Program for Managing the Problem

fields.description: Discussion of AKC, USDAA, NADAC, ASCA, DOCNA, TDAA, CKC, AAC qualifying rates.
fields.tags: AAC AKC ASCA CKC DOCNA NADAC TDAA USDAA
fields.series: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Agility
fields.title: Qualifying rates in organizations.

fields.description: This basic setup is great for working on your dog's responsiveness to your handling.
fields.title: A Favorite Setup

fields.description: Balance in agility training is important. Not only do you need balance in the actual behaviors that you work on with your dog, but you also need balance in the philosophical way that you approach dog training and agility in particular.
fields.title: Balance in Training

fields.description: Once you have built your foundation skills to a high level, you can add them into your daily life. Here are the most common ways to set up desensitization sessions for you and your dog.
fields.series: You Know Your Dog Is Aggressive If...
fields.title: Part 4

fields.description: Weave pole foundation training often neglects to thoroughly test a dog’s understanding of entries early in the process. Instant recognition of entries at speed, given any circumstance or set of variables, should be trained and tested long before a dog is weaving 6 or 12 poles. These drills all have challenging weave pole entries and exits.
fields.title: Weave Pole Entries and Exits

fields.description: This month’s exercises concentrate on the handler’s and dog’s ability to rapidly shift from obstacle focus to handler focus multiple times. They also provide the freedom for handlers to create their own courses rather than dictating a set exercise pattern.
fields.title: Switching Obstacle and Handler Focus

fields.description: Finding and entering trials requires attention to detail and can be confusing for newcomers to the sport. Here we discuss the basics of finding and entering agility trials in the U.S.
fields.title: How to Find and Enter Trials

fields.description: Many competitors don’t know anything about the people who help organize and orchestrate most aspects of this well-loved sport. This month you’ll meet Linda Eickholdt (CPE), Jim and Mary Kay Mills (DOCNA), Laura Derrett (UKI), and Carrie DeYoung (AKC).
fields.title: Part 2

fields.description: While many competitors dream of earning titles, animal shelters continue to house dogs that were relinquished because they are too energetic, too smart, or too busy for most pet homes. Many of these dogs are great agility prospects. This month, meet Panic, a mixed breed dog.
fields.title: Panic

fields.description: Too much training can decrease athletic performance and cause physical and mental stress as well as injuries in both humans and dogs. Learn how to avoid overtraining so that you and your dog can compete at your best and also enjoy what you’re doing.
fields.title: How Overtraining Affects Us and Our Dogs

fields.description: Can you tell the difference between aspiration and expectation? One is a harmful distraction and the other is about realizing your team's full potential.
fields.title: Aspiration versus Expectation

fields.series: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Agility
fields.title: What is a viaduct jump?

fields.description: Sending and picking up the dog out of the tunnel.
fields.title: Tunnel Skills
